docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON - The military's No. 1 priority is fighting the nation's wars, but No. 2 is taking care of the troops that fight those wars.

headline.main: Joint Chiefs Support Rise in Health Care Fees for Military Retirees

docs.abstract: With Congress demanding that the government cut spending, the expensive military health care system was bound to become a target. But the Pentagon is making the first move to reduce its own costs.
docs.snippet: With Congress demanding that the government cut spending, the expensive military health care system was bound to become a target. But the Pentagon is making the first move to reduce its own costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

docs.lead_paragraph: Searing rises in health costs have reopened the pledges made to local government workers, past and present.

headline.seo: States and Cities Grapple With Retiree Health Costs
headline.main: States Aim Ax at Health Cost of Retirement
headline.print_headline: States Aim Ax At Health Cost Of Retirement

docs.snippet: Searing rises in health costs have reopened the pledges made to local government workers, past and present.

docs.lead_paragraph: Governors and mayors facing large deficits have set their sights on a relatively new target -- the soaring expense of health benefits for millions of retired state and local workers. As they contend with growing budget deficits and higher pension costs, some mayors are complaining that their outlays for retiree health benefits are rising by 20 percent a year -- a result of the wave of retirements of baby boomers and longer life expectancies on top of the double-digit rate of health care inflation.

headline.main: States Aim Ax At Health Cost Of Retirement

docs.abstract: Governors and mayors across the country facing large deficits are looking at soaring expense of health benefits for millions of retired state and local workers; Center for State and Local Government Excellence finds that 68 percent of city and county officials are pushing to have retirees assume more of their health costs, while 39 percent say they have eliminated or planned to eliminate retiree health benefits for new hires; photo (M)
